Message.Title: Best trades of 2012 - Yahoo!
Message.Msg: Year-to-Date: Up 21 Percent Now for the best trades of 2012. With Marissa Meyer at the helm — a new CEO with a Google pedigree — Yahoo saw its stock price run up to its highest level in four years. Some have questioned whether the positive sentiment is justified, but so far Meyer has upped spending on advertising and quickly closed the nearly $8 billion Alibaba deal, all while improving employee morale. For now, Wall Street is willing to give Meyer the benefit of the doubt. http://www.cnbc.com/id/100333015/page/7

Topic.Title: Yahoo Updates Message Board Format

Message.Msg: I've been a basher of yahoo in the past 6 months. I didn't like what they did to product lines including message board. i like what I see today. i think no live links is to prevent spam and I'm sure there are clever ways to get around it on a post. The live edit is interesting concept, while popular in more specialized boards (specific sports message boards etc), but in loosely controlled environment with no moderators to make sure people don't get out of line, letting someone edit their posts just seem to be a frivolous option IMHO. And lastly, their user database must be huge, so allowing editing might be more of a technical issue.

Topic.Title: buyout

Message.Msg: The CEO isn't worth diddly in a buyout and even if you say she's worth $120M, that's only .10 to the share price. How do you get $30? I'll give a rough ballpark...$6.4B(was $8.4 but Uncle Sam gets $2B) cash, another $1B in accounts receivables, short-term investment account etc., $7.5B in Yahoo Japan gives us say $5B after-taxes, AG stake that 10% is gone at IPO so lets say $70B so $7B gives us say $5B. We're at 17.4B cash let's say $17.5B as you'd have slightly more in Yahoo Japan in my example. $17.5B plus that last AG stake let's say for arguments sake is $150B company so $13B after-tax. $30B cash/1.2B is $25 per share. Is the core worth $5 per share or $6B? That number rises with most of that money off-shore and subject to repatriation. I'm being generous on what AG IPO's at and what that last stake is worth. A likely offer would be towards the $25 so that way an acquirer has room to work with and a chance to get a return on their investment...MSFT firing everybody, doubling net income, gives them $10 per share of return IMO as an example.
